marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Samuel G. Hunt was a Confederate soldier; from Forestvillle, Wake County, North Carolina.

Principally the Civil War correspondence between Samuel G. Hunt, a Confederate soldier, and his wife describing camp life and conditions at home. Included are land deeds, 1777-1842, in Granville County, North Carolina.
John Hughes was a resident of Burke County, North Carolina.
Benjamin Huger was an artillery expert, from Charleston, South Carolina.

Principally correspondence dealing with the manufacture of ammunition by Joseph Reid Anderson and Dr. Carmichael for Fortress Monroe and the armory at Harper's Ferry, Va. (now W. Va.), 1850-1851. Also included are a letter of 1803 from Daniel Huger, secretary of state, to the South Carolina legislature requesting an appropriation for the repair of the building where the records were kept; an indenture, 1824; a letter from John P. Martin discussing the problems of the mail and stage service; and letter, 1862, of Huger to Josiah Tattnall concerning military and naval operations in Virginia.
Receipt from Coles Creek Cotton Gin to Jacob Cable of Huntston.
Ben Hubert was a Confederate soldier, 6th Regiment, Louisiana Volunteers, and resident of Bryan (Brazos County), Texas.

Principally love letters written during the Civil War to Hubert's future wife, Letitia Bailey. There are scattered references to a fight on the Potomac, 1861; the fall of New Orleans, 1862; a request for Letitia to make a "battle flag"; the town of Bryan, Tex.; and a reunion of Hood's Brigade, 1876. Also included is some correspondence of Hubbard's sisters.
Henry Hukill was a Steubenville, Ohio resident temporarily employed in Louisiana.

This collection contains five letters. Four are from brothers Henry and William Hukill to other relatives back home in Steubenville, Ohio. Two of these letters are written in New Orleans and two in Natchez where the Hukills have gone to work. The other letter is from Thirza Hukill in Steubenville to her husband Henry. The Hukills made several trips from Ohio to work in La. and Miss. The topics covered include family, health, and money matters. Economic conditions in both Natchez and New Orleans are discussed, and a brief comparison is made between wages in New Orleans, Steubenville, and Natchez. However, neither Henry nor William's occupation is stated. Henry mentions the specific wage rate in Natchez. He also discusses the costs of various food items and whiskey in Natchez. There is also a general description of the climate in New Orleans.
Robert Mercer Taliaferro Hunter was a Richmond, Virginia, lawyer and statesman.
Letter from Hunter to C.G. Griswold of Essex, Virginia. It concerns a proposal relative to banking and compromise resolutions on the abolition question.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession records.
Henry Huntington was a benefactor of the American Colonization Society; resident of Rome, Oneida County, New York.

Collection includes letters appealing for financial support from Huntington for the American Colonization Society, most of them from Rev. Alexander Moncrief Proudfit, Corresponding Secretary of the New York Chapter of the Society. Huntington writes of the schism in churches between supporters of the colonization movement and some who feel the Society is a proslavery organization. Proudfit writes about the work that Huntington's money is going toward, such as transportation for the Governor of Liberia to sail from colony to colony. Enclosed in one of Proudfit's letters is a circular with a letter from Samuel Benedict, who had migrated from Georgia to Liberia. Proudfit appeals for money in other letters and he also includes another letter from a former slave. One circular letter is from Nathaniel Shatswell Dodge, Agent of the American Colonization Society. The collection holds a great deal of information on the work of the Society in Liberia. Two clippings are also included.
Andrew H. Hunter was a lawyer and Whig politician. General Andrew Hunter was Marshal of the District of Columbia.
Letter from Andrew H. Hunter to William Beale; and a letter to General Andrew Hunter from a clerk who considered himself underpaid.
Alexander von Humboldt was a German naturalist and traveler.
Washington Hunt was comptroller of New York and later governor.
Letter to Washington Hunt concerning a claim for a pension for the widow of a Continental Army officer.
George N. Huckins was a Methodist minister, resident of Cuyahoga County, Ohio.

Diary (63 pages) kept while Huckins was a student at Baldwin University (now Baldwin-Wallace College) in Berea, and while serving several churches in northern Ohio. Short, introspective entries generally relate to his doubts about his qualifications as a minister and to his matrimonial prospects, with brief references to his school activities and studies, John Brown, James Buchanan, the election of Lincoln and the beginning of the Civil War, and slavery.
E. J. Humphries, a member of the Governor's Horse Guards; resident of Milledgevllle, Georgia.
Letters, 1861, of E. J. Humphries while at Camp Davis, Lynchburg, Virginia; a letter, 1869, from an Augusta, Georgia, commission merchant to Humphries.
Daniel Huntington was a painter, of New York, New York.

Letters to Daniel Huntington from J. Strickler Jenkins concerning Jenkins's portrait, from John Bigelow pertaining to a portrait of Samuel J. Tilden, and from Philip Henry Sheridan discussing Sheridan's portrait.
James Hunter was a resident of Augusta, Georgia.
Confederate army orders concerning the defense of Savannah, signed by James Hunter for the acting adjutant general.
William W. Hunter was a Confederate naval commander, stationed in Savannah, Georgia.

Letters to Hunter from Sidney Smith Lee, captain in charge of the Office of Orders and Detail, C.S.A. Navy Department, from John M. Brooke, commander in charge of the Office of Ordnance and Hydrography, C.S.A. Navy Dept., and from other naval officers regarding ships, supplies, watchwords, men absent without leave and deserters, courts-martial, the laying of torpedoes in the harbor of Savannah, and other naval matters, with numerous references to various Confederate ships.
Elijah Huntley was a farmer in Deep Creek, Anson County. North Carolina.

Personal correspondence of Elijah Huntley, including letters from a friend at Pine Bluff, Arkansas, describing the countryside, inhabitants, and agricultural and economic conditions; a letter of similar nature concerning Houston County, Georgia; and papers relating to the estate of Lewis Griggs for which Huntley was administrator.
Personal letter to Pleasant Hunt from his niece in Salem, Iowa.
Ossian Huggins was a resident of Summerville (Chattooga County), Georgia.

Personal letters of Ossian Huggins while he was a student at Washington College, Lexington, Virginia, commenting on courses offered, requirements for obtaining degrees, and Robert E. Lee as president of the College. Included are two letters from a later period.
Robert W. Hughes was a United States judge for the district of Eastern Virginia, Confederate soldier, and candidate for governor of Virginia, 1873.
Letters containing recommendations for political appointments for the eastern part of Virginia.
Eppa Hunton was a brigadier general in the Confederate Army, of Warrenton (Fauquier County), Virginia.

Business letters of Eppa Hunton concerning his legal practice in Washington, D.C.; personal letters commenting on Confederate veteran's reunions; a letter of recommendation; and a calling card with a note by Hunton.
Charles Hudson was a politician and author in Lexington, Middlesex County, Massachusetts.
William Henry Hunt was Secretary of the Navy, 1881-1882.

Letter by Hunt to the Acting Attorney General, S.F. Phillips, regarding the case of William Wallace. Wallace, a Captain in the U.S. Marine Corps, had evidently brought suit against the Navy Department for its alleged non-payment of salary increments.
Unprocessed collection. Cataloged from accession records.
Nicholas Collin Hughes was an Episcopal minister, of Chocowinity, Beaufort County, North Carolina.
Letters from Collier Cobb, Thomas Egleston, and Samuel Hart to Nicholas C. Hughes, criticising his work, GENESIS AND GEOLOGY; and a personal letter from his brother, John Hughes.
Charles H. Hull, professor at Cornell University, Ithaca, New York.
Letters from Charles H. Hull to W. H. Glasson, professor at Trinity College, Durham, North Carolina, concerning the resignation of John Spencer Bassett.
Martin A. S. Hume was a British historian.
Letters from Hume to Mrs. Stuart Erskine concerning suggestions for books to be included in the Romance of History series.
